response.answer_text: Sure. If you grew up in an organised framework of meaning, and became disillusioned with it, read some constructivism or cultural relativism and realised it was all a social construct, and oh my, everything is a social construct, and oh my there is no intrinsic meaning in the universe, just the cold light of dying stars and infinite freezing void in between them… And if you then went and jumped off a building as a result: that would be misguided. Think instead of someone you love, past or present. Then see how particular and accidental that love is. If it’s your parent, they could have died when you were younger; the egg could have been hit by a different sperm and produced someone else; you could have died before term. Do the same if it’s a sibling or child. Let’s say it’s your beloved partner. There are a hundred way you could have never met them. Or maybe they could have already been partnered. Or you never had that special time which caused you to fall into love with each other. That love you have of a particular person is the product of a thousand accidents. It’s what’s called “contingent”. Then there’s Universal Love, Timeless Love, Cosmic Love. Not love of any particular human, just a vast universal abstraction. Compare the value of the two objects of love. Which keeps you warm at night? Which warms your heart. Which are you most afraid of losing? Which leads you to be happy when you see them. Particular love is real and powerful. Universal love is imagined and powerless. Life meaning comes from the particular, not the universal, and it’s only because have been raised to value the universal that we sometimes fail to see that. Why have we been so trained? Because that training makes us better organisational employees, church-goers, state-citizens, and soldiers. There’s nothing wrong with any of those institutions or roles as long as we don’t drink the Kool-Aid they’re selling to recruit you. The ultimate response to finding out that both love and meaning are particular and contingent should not be “I must go jump off a building”, but rather “thank goodness.” Because particular and contingent also means that you can do something about it.
